TopicTitle: Flickering shadows when returning to KSC from solar orbiter

Articles.Content:
(Windows 32-bit, 0.25, Steam, Nvidia GTX 770M with KSP settings "optimized" -- basically, maximum resolution)

I first noticed this on a heavily-modded, well-used save, but I was able to recreate it on a fresh stock save.

Steps to reproduce:

1) Launch a vehicle into solar orbit (the Kerbal X can do this), wait for it to escape from Kerbin.

2) Return to Kerbal Space Center.

3) Move the viewpoint around to find the "sour spot" -- it's usually a to the right of the default position in the morning or early afternoon, and it's pretty close around 4:30 or so.

4) Observe flickering shadows, like looking at a CRT monitor through a video camera with a different frame rate, especially noticeable around the research labs and the roof of the tracking center. They also pause when the game pauses, or when I mouse over the bar at the bottom of the screen.

I've got some screenshots in this imgur album.

This only happens when going from a Sun-orbiting vessel to KSC -- even entering and leaving one of the KSC buildings is enough to clear it up. The interesting thing I noticed when I looked at output_log is that, when I switched from the Sun-orbiting vessel to the space center, PlanetariumCamera focused on the Mun, whereas when I switched from a Kerbin-orbiting vessel to the space center (or from the space center to the tracking center), PlanetariumCamera focused on Kerbin. I wonder if that's part of the cause -- if the Camera is looking at KSC but thinks it's on the Mun, maybe there's some kind of massive disparity in some of the floating-point numbers (the shadows are only a few meters or tens of meters in size, while it thinks its distance to the objects being imaged is something like 12 Mm) causing some funky rounding or machine-epsilon errors.
